original_title: USAID to provide technical assistance for Sri Lanka’s energy reforms
original_body_lines: ECONOMYNEXT – The United States Agency for International Development (USAID) has made available its technical assistance in restructuring Sri Lanka’s energy sector and developing a roadmap for reforming the state-run Ceylon Electricity Board (CEB).

Power & Energy Minister Kanchana Wijesekara tweeted Monday May 08 afternoon that he had met a USAID delegation along with  Arindam Ghosh, the consultant assigned to the reform project that will take place over the next eight weeks.

USAID has made available its technical assistance for the restructuring of the energy sector & to develop the roadmap for the transition of CEB reforms. Met with Mr Arindam Ghosh, the assigned consultant & the USAID team this morning, that will develop the road map & assist in… pic.twitter.com/dtZ9qVrC1m

Sri Lanka’s proposed energy sector reforms, particularly consequent to its ongoing International Monetary Fund (IMF) programme, has been politically sensitive with various groups including sections of the opposition accusing the government of “selling national assets”.
The government has defended its moves to restructure loss-making state-owned enterprises (SOEs) as being necessary for the economy to recover and for Sri Lanka’s long term development.
Sri Lanka is set to  sign fuel retail agreements with China’s state-owned petroleum corporation Sinopec and the US based RM Park-Shell in May with operations to commence sometime in June.
Meanwhile, chairman of the power regulator Public Utilities Commission of Sri Lanka (PUCSL) Janaka Ratnayake has said the government plans to break the state-run CEB to 14 different companies.

Sri Lanka’s power sector has come under corruption allegations due to a model of having a single buyer for electricity leading to lobbying to pay artificially high tariffs without tender through standardized power purchase agreements as well as take-or-pay deals for LNG according to critics.
